query: I'm 16 and help care for my mother who has MS in manchester. This is affecting my schoolwork. Is there any support for young carers?

retrieved_documents.content: . We understand the challenges faced by young people who care, and our specialist workers can give you advice and support as well as putting you in touch with other young carers. Make contact Manchester City Council and the NHS work in partnership with ‘ Carers Manchester ’ a network of local Carers organisations, and we encourage all people with a caring responsibility to make contact with the Carers Manchester Contact Point , to find out what support would be helpful to you, now or in the future. You can also join the Carers Register so that we can keep in touch about local services and support. Learn more and get in touch: visit www.carersmanchester.org.uk for information speak to one our specialist Carers Contact Advisors on 0161 543 8000 (Monday to Friday 10am to 4pm except bank holidays)

. We understand the challenges faced by young people who care, and our specialist workers can give you advice and support as well as putting you in touch with other young carers. Make contact Manchester City Council and the NHS work in partnership with ‘ Carers Manchester ’ a network of local Carers organisations, and we encourage all people with a caring responsibility to make contact with the Carers Manchester Contact Point , to find out what support would be helpful to you, now or in the future. You can also join the Carers Register so that we can keep in touch about local services and support. Learn more and get in touch: visit www.carersmanchester.org.uk for information speak to one our specialist Carers Contact Advisors on 0161 543 8000 (Monday to Friday 10am to 4pm except bank holidays)

. Your rights to a young carers needs assessment and support. Putting you in touch with other young carers you can talk to. Call us on 0161 234 5001. If you don’t feel comfortable speaking to us, why not talk to a teacher? They will be able to give you advice on what to do and may well have had students who were carers before There’s lots of information and support available to young carers and resources available to practitioners supporting young carers. See Help and Support Manchester. Was this page helpful? Was this page helpful? Fields marked * cannot be left blank Yes No What were you doing? * What went wrong? * What were you looking for? * How can we make this page better? * Feedback submitted to us on this form is monitored but you won’t receive a reply. In an emergency, visit our emergency contact details page . Please don't include any personal or financial information, for example your National Insurance or credit card numbers.

Social services Caring for someone Covid-19 Additional guidance and support is available through the Carers Manchester website. Ongoing support for carers Caring can take on many forms, including preparing meals, doing shopping, taking someone to appointments, managing finances, bathing or toileting, giving medication or emotional support, or doing laundry.  People of all ages can become carers, including children and young people. If you support a relative, friend or neighbour, because of their age, physical or learning disability, mental illness or substance misuse (drugs or alcohol) and you are not paid for the support you provide, then you can get advice, support and training to help you in your caring role. Support from us We know caring brings many rewards, but it can also be stressful and may affect your own health

Social services Caring for someone Covid-19 Additional guidance and support is available through the Carers Manchester website. Ongoing support for carers Caring can take on many forms, including preparing meals, doing shopping, taking someone to appointments, managing finances, bathing or toileting, giving medication or emotional support, or doing laundry.  People of all ages can become carers, including children and young people. If you support a relative, friend or neighbour, because of their age, physical or learning disability, mental illness or substance misuse (drugs or alcohol) and you are not paid for the support you provide, then you can get advice, support and training to help you in your caring role. Support from us We know caring brings many rewards, but it can also be stressful and may affect your own health

. For most young people Personal Advisers have a duty to keep in touch regularly until the age of 21 years and this is something that you can ask to continue after this age also. We will consider the support needs of all Manchester care leavers in the city when offering support and assistance to achieve and succeed involving all relevant services and professionals. What you're entitled to ask for Health and wellbeing Recognition of your care experience in your adult health records so this can be supported in appointments or when you are accessing support. Access to Manchester MIND counselling via the Community Hub. Access to 42nd Street emotional health and wellbeing support via the Community Hub. Access to all health records and a final health plan when your turn 18 years. Support to access to leisure activities and local clubs. Dedicated support for young adults 18+ to keep healthy and active as part of the Community Hub. Housing Access to funds to support setting up your first home

. Support for Young Parents: Additional resources if you’re a young parent. Ongoing Support: Continued assistance beyond age 18, involving Adult Social Care if needed. Leisure Facilities: Free or discounted entry to select leisure facilities in Manchester. Community Events: Access social and community events to keep you active and connected with others. Trauma-Informed Support: Opportunities to build skills and reflect on your journey using a trauma-informed approach. A member of our Leaving Care team can also accompany you to medical appointments to ensure you receive the support and advice you need. Useful Contacts and Services for Health and Wellbeing If you need assistance with your health and wellbeing, the following services are available to you: Leaving Care - Duty Support If your Personal Advisor (PA) is unavailable and you need urgent support, call the duty line at 0161 227 3030

People and communities Help for families and children Free school meals and free school travel School holidays Help with school uniform costs Free childcare Health advice and food vouchers Money in a crisis Free and cheap ways to get online Support and advice services Support and advice services Visit our Family Hubs , bringing together services for families with children of all ages (0-19) or up to 25 with special educational needs and disabilities (SEND). Get support and advice for young people at www.42ndstreet.org.uk . Dad Matters helps dads whose partners are pregnant or who have a baby aged under 2. They run support groups for dads at antenatal clinics and classes. They also provide outreach for antenatal care. You can refer yourself or someone else for support Mums Matter - An 8-week course held at various locations in Manchester. It’s designed by mums for mums, helping new mothers with kids under 2

Social services Rights and entitlements As a care leaver in Manchester there are things we will support you with to help you get on in life and succeed, including: Making sure you have someone there to support when you need them. Support to have happy and healthy relationships with those important to you. Support with understanding, managing and assisting with finances. Making sure we support you to have a safe place to live, access housing that meets your need and sustain your own home. Support with information, guidance and access to education & training opportunities as well as employment. Depending upon your journey through care and current circumstances there may be different rights and entitlements. All care experienced young people have a right to an assessment to consider their needs or a change in circumstances. For most young people Personal Advisers have a duty to keep in touch regularly until the age of 21 years and this is something that you can ask to continue after this age also

Social services Young people who are planning on or who have become parents We want to be there for you when you need us to ensure you have the best start to pregnancy and parenting. It is an exciting time and a wonderful milestone to reach. All Manchester's Family Hubs and Sure Start Children’s Centres have dedicated Care Leaver Champions who have specialist training in supporting care leavers as parents in the community. You don’t need a Personal Adviser to access this support however we are here and on hand to introduce you to services that are there for you. Sure Start Children Centres are places where children under 5 and their families can access a wide range of support services and information e.g. early education, childcare, health, and family support. There are also Family Outreach Workers that can support families who need additional support and understand care leavers can need addition support, especially if you are a first time parent

answer:
As a young carer in Manchester, there is support available to help you manage your responsibilities and schoolwork. You can access advice and support through Carers Manchester, a network of local carers' organizations.

- **Contact Carers Manchester**: You can speak to specialist Carers Contact Advisors by calling **0161 543 8000** (Monday to Friday, 10 am to 4 pm, except bank holidays) or visit their website at [www.carersmanchester.org.uk](http://www.carersmanchester.org.uk) for more information.

- **Young Carers Needs Assessment**: You have the right to a young carers needs assessment to determine the support you require. You can call **0161 234 5001** for more information or speak to a teacher at your school, who can provide advice and support.

- **Join the Carers Register**: This allows Manchester City Council to keep in touch with you about local services and support.

For further assistance and resources, you can explore the "Help and Support Manchester" site, which offers information specifically for young carers.

test_metadata.prompt_template:
Please answer the following question about social care services in UK local authorities based only on the information in the provided documents.

Question: {query}

Context from relevant documents:
{context}

Instructions:
1. Provide a clear, direct answer that would help someone needing this information. If information isn't available, state: "The available documents don't provide specific information about [aspect]."

2. Synthesize information from ALL relevant documents to provide the most complete answer rather than analyzing documents individually.

3. Structure your response with:
   - A concise 1-2 sentence summary first
   - Relevant details organized in short, clear paragraphs
   - Bullet points for lists or step-by-step information
   - Bold text for key information the user should notice

4. For financial information:
   - Include exact figures, time periods, and what the funding covers
   - Present financial data clearly: "The adult social care budget is **£X million** for [time period]"

5. Always include practical next steps or resources:
   - Provide contact information, URLs, or application methods mentioned in the documents
   - Suggest where the person could find more information

6. When citing sources, use a simple format: "According to [document name/description]" or include URLs where available.

Answer:
